comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/] Thanks for posting this so quickly. I was amazed to discover where this handsome and very old building was - at the SE corner of George and Market Streets, in the middle of Sydney. Unfortunately it literally has "Gone to Gowings", with the 1929 Gowings building at 452-56 George St., and the 1929 State Theatre in Market St. there now. Google Maps Street View - g.co/maps/d5ekf Gowings - www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/07_subnav_04_2.cfm?itemid=2424014 State Theatre - www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/07_subnav_04_2.cfm?itemid=5045499 and www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/07_subnav_04_2.cfm?itemid=2424031 I am not sure what the old building was called or used for, or its date (c.1830?) - does anyone know? Did it survive into the 1920s, or was there another building before Gowings? It seems to have been unloved towards the end of the C19th - most photographs seem to avoid it.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Aha! Found it! Joseph Fowles "Sydney in 1848" names it as Waterloo Stores -
" At the corner of Market Street, with the front in George Street, stands the "Waterloo Stores," a spacious brick building, erected some twenty years since by Mr. Daniel Cooper; it then stood alone at the corner of the Cattle Market, and was without question the best building in the City, and even in the present day, when the spirit and enterprise of the colonists have caused the erection of many very excellent buildings, it still holds its rank amongst the best. The business of this establishment is conducted by Mr. D. Cooper, Junior, (the son of the above named gentleman) on a very extended scale. Country Stores and Settlers are here supplied with every thing they require: Wines, Spirits, Ales and Porter, Grocery, and Drapery Goods, Slops, and Clothing, Ironmongery, etc., in infinite variety. "
from - www.sydneyarchitecture.com/GALL/GALL-1848.htm (just over half way down). There is a recognisable illustration (top left) -

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: It is easy when you have the name. The Waterloo Stores was demolished in 1883 - "The last of the Waterloo Stores" SLNSW

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: And John Hunter (Boots - next door} took over the George St frontage and erected another building which was demolished for Gowings. Daniel Cooper had acquired the site in 1821 and started building that year. Ref - SMH 17/10/1928, p.11 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16502273 . So the Waterloo Stores was there from 1821- 1883. I imagine this photo is shortly before the 1883 demolition. What a great big shame, but how lucky that someone had the idea to photograph it.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content:
Well done Beachcomber, I enjoyed your research.
George Street seems to be still paved in wood block? Did they ever use stone pavers?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] Thanks! I am not sure the street is wood-blocked yet. I did a bit of Troving and found an 1885 article saying "Although the wood pavement in George-street between Market and Park streets has been laid only a couple of years [ie 1883], a large portion of it is now undergoing repairs." SMH 03/09/1885, p.9, bottom of column 1 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/page/1405142 . If that is woodblocking, that is further proof that this photo is 1883. Pellethepoet will know! I don't know if they ever used stone pavers. Most descriptions mention dust when it was dry, and mud when wet, which implies not.

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content:
"...Waterloo Warehouse

On the south-east corner of George and Market streets (where Hunter's shop stands), there stood for some 60 years a large building, which was a monument to a man who also came from obscurity to greatness; but in this case he became a power in the financial, not the political, world. This gentleman was Mr. Daniel Cooper, the proprietor of the Waterloo warehouse. Portions of the old building still form part of the "Evening News" offices.

The warehouse, then known as the Lachlan and Waterloo Stores, the proprietors of which were Messrs. Cooper and Levy, was situated at first on the corner of King and George streets, but in the "Sydney Gazette" of May 6, 1821, it was announced that the warehouse had been removed to George and Market streets. This latter site comprised the greater part of an allotment leased by Governor Macquarie to James Smith, on January 2, 1819, for 14 years. It was sold by auction on February 13, 1821, and purchased by Daniel Cooper.

Cooper and Levy called for tenders at the end of that year for the stone and brick work of a new warehouse. Mr. Levy afterwards dropped out as a partner, and was replaced by Mr. Holt. The firm did a large country business, supplemented by banking and money-lending. They issued what were known as Waterloo notes, one of the few paper currencies which were always worth their face value.

Sir Daniel Cooper, a nephew of the original Cooper, was afterwards a partner in the firm. When Anthony Trollope visited Australia, in 1871, he dined at Woollahra House one night with Sir Daniel Cooper, and said of Woollahra:

"It is a magnificent property, covered with villas and gardens, all looking down upon a glorious sea. In England it would be worth half a million of money, and as things go on it will soon be worth as much in New South Wales. And perhaps some future Cooper will be Duke Cooper or Marquis Cooper, and Woollahra will be as famous as Lowther or Chatsworth. It is infinitely more lovely than either. I envied the young man, and almost hated him for having it—although he had just given me an excellent dinner"

(THE STORY OF OLD GEORGE STREET. BY CHARLES H. BERTIE)

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Looking at the large size, George Street doesn't appear to be wood-blocked. I can't see any tell-tale signs, but it could just be hidden under a fresh layer of sand (but I don't think so). The demolition photo however shows the street was wood-blocked at the time of demolition in 1883. Lee and Ross, Printers [see note] were also champion cricketers. There is an 1883 newspaper article noting their victory in the "Printer's Cup" over Gibbs, Shallard & Co. (who I'm pretty sure were the Government Printer) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/70999434

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Rossalie, Lloyd & Co. [see note] of London and Paris advertised on 11 December 1882 that a Junior Partner in their firm (Thomas J. Lloyd) had procured a temporary showroom at 454 George Street above John Hunter's City Boot Palace [trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13518037 4th column, towards the bottom]. The showroom held it's gala opening at 10am, Monday 18 December 1882 [trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13518945 last column]. In March 1883 Rossalie, Lloyd & Co. informed the ladies of the colony of their plans to move to permanent premises near the GPO at 354 George Street [trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/70997593 2nd column, bottom]. In July 1883 they held a sale in anticipation of their imminent move [trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13538771 2nd column, near the bottom] and by August 1883 they were operating at their new address [trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/71002531 3rd column, near the bottom]. This dates our photo to between December 1882 - July/August 1883.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Sounds good to me, as demolition was imminent, and this would give a strong reason for the photograph of the building being taken. Thursday 7 June 1883 - TENDERS will be received up to the 23rd for the Erection of Shops, Offices, and Photographic Gallery at the corner of George-street and Market-street, known as the "Waterloo Stores," as follows :- 1st. Excavators, Masonry, and Brickwork 2nd. Carpenters, Joiners, and Finishing Trades 3rd. The Whole in one sum. Plans and specifications, and full particulars, may be obtained at the office of THOMAS ROWE, Architect, Vickery's-chambers. Pitt-street. - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13536411 [2nd column, centre]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] Ok, I concede - I've found evidence it must have been wood-blocked, as the wood-blocking was laid down on this section of George Street between Market Street and Park Street in October 1882. From Sydney Municipal Council minutes reported in SMH on Wednesday 14 February 1883 - During the past half-year the only addition to the wood-paving system is that part of George-street between Market and Park streets, which has now been open for traffic since October, 1882, and is in every respect satisfactory. I venture to hope that this class of road paving will be largely extended, as it has now been sufficiently long in use for its excellence to become appreciated by the public. - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/28375561 [1st column, half-way-down]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
I wonder if this image has something to do with the photo of the 1882 Farmer & Co. building across Market St.  (nb also edge of wood blocks,  see note).  The contrast of the old and new stores must have been very striking in 1883 -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4886221629/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The similarities between this building and the 1819 Hyde Park Barracks are also striking. I wonder if Francis Greenway (architect) was involved? He certainly knew Daniel Cooper (the uncle) - The Australian 19/12/1824 p.4 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/37073213 . [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23268776@N03/3277691067/]Hyde Park Barracks - Sydney - 1819 (DBHKerr)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
YES! The Waterloo Stores building was designed by Francis Greenway. From the Dictionary of Sydney's page on the State Theatre -
" The site of the State Theatre had earlier been the location of Daniel Cooper's Waterloo Stores, a Greenway-designed building probably constructed in the 1820s. This was replaced with offices for the Evening News, a daily Sydney newspaper, in the late nineteenth century. "

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Well, not a completely accurate statement from the Dictionary of Sydney there. The Evening News offices only occupied part of the former Waterloo Stores site. Always worth checking primary sources when you can - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a1367430.html (1887 map) Most of the rest of the site, including the important corner site, was in fact occupied by a brand-spanking new Boot Palace - yep, our very own John Hunter, the boot seller next door. - MR. JOHN HUNTER'S NEW CITY BOOT PALACE, GEORGE AND MARKET STREETS, SYDNEY, Bathurst Free Press and Mining Journal, 11 April 1885 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/62014155 [Note newspaper illustration!]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Greenway Lane, The Rocks - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet/6405411789/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] Hey Highranger, re your question about stone pavers - "Experiments with sandstone proved a failure in heavy traffic areas as stone paving readily wore and cracked. Woodblocks were selected because they reduced noise, looked attractive, minimised dust, were durable and easily cleaned. Australia also had an ample supply of suitable hardwood timber." - thedirton.therocks.com/2010/03/telling-rocks-stories-hist... The blog entry includes a photo of George Street around 1880, showing stone paving prior to the adoption of woodblocks.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] I think the Dictionary of Sydney was just talking about the State Theatre site (which then makes sense). The Town and Country Journal was also planning to go there in 05/01/1884 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/71007225 - " ... now erecting an establishment in Market-street , near George-street, on the site of the old Waterloo Stores ... ". Btw the T&CJ have an illustration of New Years celebrations 1879 showing the Waterloo Stores - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/70934184 . John Hunter's City Boot Palace illustration rang a bell. Charles Kerry, c.1905 - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2362677039/] Trying to find primary source proof of the Francis Greenway connection, which adds huge interest to the photo, imho ... [update] - Francis Greenway was the attributed architect of Daniel Cooper's private residence, Cleveland House (1823-4), still there but sadly neglected - www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/07_subnav_02_2.cfm?itemid=5045140 [Google Street View - g.co/maps/q4gnz ]

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Sydney was sold the geological "Pup" in regards to our Hawkesbury sandstone.Not very good quality at all. You probably know that most of Sydney's street curbing is the much harder Trachyte brought all the way up from The Gib at Bowral. The volcano at the bottom of my garden is made of the same stuff! ;-)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
The tender for the new stores in November 1821 - Sydney Gazette and NSW Advertiser, Saturday 17/11/1821, p.2, col.1 (near the bottom) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/2180603
" WANTED, by the LACHLAN and WATERLOO COMPANY, 20,000 FEET of SAWED TIMBER---- "Bill of Scantling to be seen at the Company's Warehouse;" 300,000 BRICKS, of the best Quality, and full Size; and 300 BUSHELS of ROACH LIME. The whole to be delivered on the Premises in George-street. Any Person or Persons wishing to Contract for all, or any Part of the above Materials, will send in sealed Tenders for Cash. The necessary Securities for the due Performance will be required. "
Which implies the building date was likely to be 1822. btw the link above, next to this advert in column 2, is the news of Napoleon Bonaparte's death on St Helena. Also eggs were 1s. 6d. per dozen in 1821.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Just found an online interactive 1822 Sydney Map which shows the building (inaccurate outline) as "46 - Store of Waterloo Mills Comp[an]y.". Strikes me that the building was built right over the Tank Stream, which would have made it damp, and not improve the quality of the water downstream. www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-f107-sd&rgn=0.2...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
"THE Public are hereby informed, that the LACHLAN and WATERLOO FLOUR WAREHOUSE is removed from George-street King-street, to George-street Corner of Market-street : where the Business will be carried on as usual. The Company having issued their Promissory Notes, on demand, likewise beg to state, that the Cash Office, adjoining the Flour Warehouse, will be open every Day (Sunday excepted) from Ten o'Clock until Three, for the Consolidation of the same, in Dollars, Store Receipts, or Bills on the Treasury. N.B. The Public will he accommodated, at the Cash Office, with small Change at any time within Office Hours. "
From the Sydney Gazette, 26/5/1821, p.1, col. 2. So the Waterloo Stores opened in May 1821, which doesn't correspond with the November 1821 call for tenders (see above). (As often happens, found when looking for something else!)
